title: Adaptive anxiety
display_name: Adaptive anxiety
ab: Human societies have evolved dramatically over the past few hundred years such that we might expect change to be something we are all well equipped to handle, and even embrace. To some extent that is true, but clearly much depends on how things change, how well those changes fit with our personal, social, and national narratives, and how quickly these changes occur. Perspectives on change are also influenced by how it affects the material wellbeing of individuals. Predictability is a further important factor.

title: Planetary health research digest
display_name: Planetary health research digest
ab: The EAT-Lancet Commission sets out six planetary boundaries for the food system, within which food production should operate to not jeopardise the sustainability of Earth system processes. The boundaries set targets for greenhouse gas emissions, nitrogen and phosphorus cycling, freshwater use, biodiversity loss, and land-system change at the global scale. Emma Moberg (Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Sweden) and co-authors used the EAT-Lancet boundaries and downscaled them to per-capita level in order to benchmark the environmental impacts of the Swedish diet against the boundaries. Similar to the global level, the average Swedish diet exceeded all boundaries except for water use. Sweden has established its own national environmental objectives including a set of indicators that the authors compared to the global indicators in the EAT-Lancet report. In their comparison of indicators, the authors noted that the boundaries did not account for factors such as chemical pollution or acidification, and that many aspects of the boundaries are too low in resolution to be useful in local contexts (eg, eutrophication impacts). To improve future tracking of diet sustainability, they call for improved record keeping during production and greater traceability for imported foods. Intertidal wetlands, the areas that are covered by sea at high tide and exposed to air at low tide, provide diverse habitats and many ecosystem services, such as shoreline stabilisation and storm protection. However, similar to other types of wetlands around the world, they are particularly vulnerable to anthropogenic environmental changes. The intertidal wetlands of China's continental coastline are no exception. Given the huge economic growth and development that have occurred in China since the opening up polices of the late 1970s, Song Song (Guangzhou University, China) and co-authors used historical satellite images to investigate how the distribution of intertidal wetlands has changed over this period. They found declines in the extent of the intertidal wetlands from 7848 km2 in the 1970s to 6017 km2 in 1995, which further declined to 4895 km2 in 2015, with Shandong and Jiangsu being the most affected provinces. Land reclamation was identified as the main cause of the seaward migration and width shrinkage of the intertidal wetlands over this period. Their results highlight the need to protect these vulnerable habitats, and the authors argue that protective legislation and education on ecosystem services could be ways to achieve this. Tropical forests act as carbon sinks, offsetting some of our GHG emissions. Many climate-driven vegetation models predict that this sink function will continue for several decades. The global terrestrial carbon sink does appear to be increasing, but evidence suggests that the sink strength of tropical forests could already be declining. Wannes Hubau (University of Leeds, UK) and co-authors analysed inventory data from 244 African and 321 Amazonian plots to investigate long-term changes in carbon sink strength of intact tropical forests and the drivers behind the change. They find that the sink strength of African forests remained stable until 2010, when it began to decline, in contrast to the previously documented decline in Amazonian forests since the 1990s. The divergence in sink properties was attributed to the extent to which fertilisation from the increasing concentration of atmospheric CO2 was outweighed by higher temperatures and drought, and internal forest dynamics triggering accelerated tree death. Carbon uptake by Amazon rainforests peaked in the 1990s while the African forests appear to have peaked around 2010, with declines predicted for both forests up to 2030. The authors point out that these findings indicate that peak carbon sequestration by these tropical forests occurred earlier than predicted, which means the date by which we need to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions will likely need to be brought forward. Protecting biodiversity in the face of human activity, especially when it results in changes to land use, is one of the biggest challenges facing the world. The Convention on Biological Diversity has proposed a target of conserving 30% of land and sea, but it is uncertain what degree of protection from extinction this will offer in light of future climate change. Lee Hannah (Moore Center for Science, USA) and co-authors used data on 289 219 species to map potential land conservation areas in the tropics that would minimise extinctions (up to 50% conserved land), and modelled the effects under two models of future climate change: a business-as-usual scenario (RCP 8.5) and one aiming to limit change to around 2°C (RCP 2.6). As expected, the greatest protection came at 50% conservation under RCP 2.6 with 72–82% reductions in extinctions, but even 30% conservation could reduce extinctions by 52–68% under the same scenario. The authors took species movements due to climate change into account in their spatial planning, and their findings show the importance of taking a strategic approach to conservation while also continuing efforts to minimise climate change itself.

title: A prescription for Big Oil
display_name: A prescription for Big Oil
ab: "That 'do no harm' duty that health workers have; well, if we're not addressing the fossil fuel industry, you could argue that we're neglecting that duty, because the companies are doing so much harm."

title: Nuclear war, climate change, and medical activism
display_name: Nuclear war, climate change, and medical activism
ab: Throughout the latter half of the 20th century, the world seemed poised between two outcomes: nuclear disarmament or global annihilation. As we face new threats to human health, what role does the medical community have to prevent these? “Do critics doubt that this is a medical issue?”Sidney Alexander, president of Physicians for Social Responsibility, on nuclear disarmament You must take prompt action if you think that patient safety, dignity, or comfort could be compromised. You must make sure that your conduct justifies your patients' trust in you and the public's trust in the profession. These two statements (listed in the Good Medical Practice guidelines) were used by Doctors for Extinction Rebellion in September, 2019, to justify the neglect of their normal patient duties as they lay on the ground outside the governmental Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy in London (UK). In capital letters, a fluorescent orange banner read Government Inaction Will Cost Countless Lives. Their bodies lay in unity against the inaction on climate issues that they, as guardians of health, felt obligated to oppose. The connection between environment and health is now a key concern of many medical professionals, perhaps best vocalised by WHO's declaration that “Climate change is the greatest threat to global health in the 21st century.” The climate crisis is not, however, the first issue that has compelled doctors to break the law to safeguard patient safety, dignity, and comfort. From spearheading illegal needle exchange programmes, using their bodies as blockades to stop the detention of asylum seekers, and illegally occupying government buildings to ensure continued access to medicines for people with HIV, the past century holds many examples of how the medical community can use activism—and the large moral trust the public places on them—to help confront governmental neglect on major global issues and help to abate catastrophic health outcomes. But how justified are these actions? Should nurses working in India, for example, be allowed to use their working hours and social standing to voice their concerns against destructive air pollution that, in 2017, led to 1·24 million preventable deaths in their country alone? To this day, one of the starkest risks to public health comes from the threat of nuclear warfare. Realising this connection, cardiologists Bernhard Lown (a US-born developer of the direct current defibrillator for cardiac resuscitation) and Evgeny Chazov (a Russian-born director of the Moscow Cardiological Center and a physician to former general secretaries to the communist party, such as Mikhail Gorbachev) began an unlikely collaboration. Overcoming their political differences to form International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War (IPPNW) in 1980, their exhaustive efforts to communicate the health impact of nuclear warfare—thereby reframing nuclear war as a medical issue—culminated in an unprecedented satellite teleconference between two live audiences in Moscow (Russia) and San Francisco (US). Addressing the US itself, Chazov forewarned that “If there is a nuclear war, 2 billion [people] will perish on the Earth. Civilisation will perish… the climate will be changed and there will even be the question as to whether life itself could survive… either we will live together on our beautiful planet or we will die together in the flames of a nuclear war.” In 1985, a mere 5 years after its formation, the IPPNW had over 135 000 members in 40 countries, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, and had accelerated its agenda to the scope of global concern. On the ground in the UK, the Medical Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons (MCANW) and The Medical Association for the Prevention of War (MAPW)—both UK affiliates of the IPPNW—rallied together in their thousands to stage protests, organise appeals, lobby political and military leaders, and host international conferences. Through campaigns such as Treatment not Trident in 1985 and Beds not Bombs in 1987, the aim of both organisations was to call attention to the dire medical consequences of nuclear war, the unconscionable high cost of building, testing, and maintaining nuclear warheads, and the incapacity of the National Health Service to cope with the unprecedented demand of a nuclear blast. Taras Young, author of Nuclear War in the UK, believed that medic-led activist groups, because of their medical expertise, were well positioned to argue against the use of nuclear weapons. Adopting an evidence-based approach to communicating the health dangers of nuclear weapons, as well as using their prestigious and trusted status in society, their message was clear and irrefutable, striking the core of society. “Taking a medical standpoint against nuclear weapons became a problem for the government, who could easily write off movements like the CND [Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament] as unwashed hippies”, Taras said, “but when you have a doctor saying the same thing and backing it up with a medical argument, it's much more difficult for the government to discredit.” Medic-led movements also played a corrective role in countering the unrealistic government messaging found in widely distributed public information series, such as the much derided 1980 Protect and Survive series. Discussing the accuracy of the data used in this series, Taras emphasised that “it's very likely that they [the estimated figures] were much too high in terms of how many people would survive”. Exercise Hard Rock (a simulation done by the UK Government in 1982 to estimate the impact of a nuclear blast) is another example of the government's underestimation of the damage to public health caused by nuclear warheads, which concluded that a maximum of 7·5 million people would die. Replicating the government model themselves, scientists found that the true number of deaths would be closer to 39 million deaths if the scenario was more comprehensive. As custodians of health, medical professionals were acutely aware of the potential impact on public health that a nuclear blast would have and, as such, produced pamphlets that were far more pessimistic about the effects of nuclear war than those produced by the government. The Medical Consequences of Nuclear Weapons, a 40-page pamphlet produced by MCANW and MAPW in 1982, concluded that “An examination of the facts leads to one inescapable conclusion. If for none other than purely medical reasons, nuclear warfare must never be allowed to happen.” The message could not be clearer: prevention is our only hope. The damage that is being done through climate change is, like the potential of nuclear arms, a serious threat to our planet, our people, and future. And while the bushfires that ravaged Australia between November, 2019, and January, 2020, might not have inspired the same level of fear or urgency as that of a nuclear blast, to public health officials, they were a chilling indication of the health ramifications that climate change will bring. “We are currently dealing with an enormous public health challenge”, says John McMillan, professor of bioethics at the University of Otago (Dunedin, New Zealand). “Even with the best, clearest examples of where climate change has caused harm, it's very difficult to get the evidence based public health message across.” Health professionals are once more needed, it seems, to address the failure of global leaders to properly examine the causes of, for example, Australia's so-called Black Summer and initiate serious discussions about how to address the immediate consequences of climate change on health that are unfolding at an alarming rate. Civil disobedience against the political interests stopping effective climate policy—a Treatment not Trident for our times—could represent one of the last remaining options. “Why are they [medical professionals] resorting to civil disobedience? The reason is because the conventional methods of communication on public health people use aren't getting the message across.” The immediacy of this measure reflects the immediacy of the problem, says Alex Macmillan, associate professor of environmental health at the University of Otago. “As health professionals take action, civil disobedient action included, they're communicating very clearly about the co-benefits of climate action for health and health equity.” As Lown and Chazov discovered, issues that pose catastrophic risks to health and the future of our survival are often met—paradoxically—with political and public inertia, possibly because the short-term gains of confronting these issues are hard to see and are, therefore, politically undesirable. “Our communication around [medical professionals] taking action needs to focus on shifting the framing of climate change as a remote issue (for example, about polar bears and ice caps) to being able to show the public the immediate health impacts of climate change on their lives now.” Lown and Chazov, aged 98 and 90 years, are both still alive. Unfortunately, as with all whose life's work has been dedicated to preventing apocalyptic scenarios, we cannot know for sure how much their accomplishments contributed to diverting the course of a more violent, darker history. The absolute nature of nuclear warfare means that there are no scenarios with half consequences, no half dropping of bombs—either they fall or they do not. The climate crisis is different to this. The damage we are doing to the planet, and consequently human health, is more incremental in nature. Like a cancer spreading through the body, it's happening all the time and we could make the mistake of denying it's there until it's too late. The medical community is duty-bound to act in good conscience to help avert this human calamity.

title: Road user charging: a policy whose time has finally arrived
display_name: Road user charging: a policy whose time has finally arrived

author.au_affiliation_raw: Public Health Policy Evaluation Unit, School of Public Health, Imperial College London, London W6 8RP, UK
Public Health Policy Evaluation Unit, School of Public Health, Imperial College London, London W6 8RP, UK
Centre for Diet and Activity Research, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK
Public Health Policy Evaluation Unit, School of Public Health, Imperial College London, London W6 8RP, UK

ab: “The road user should pay the costs that he/she imposes upon others.” So wrote Reuben Jacob Smeed in 1964, after being commissioned by the British government in 1962 to examine the technical feasibility of implementing road user charging (or “road pricing”).1Smeed RJ Road pricing : the economic and technical possibilities.https://archive.org/details/op1265810-1001Date: 1964Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar Smeed considered three main effects of road use: wear and tear on roads; congestion; and losses imposed on the community, including accidents, noise and fumes (which his report referred to as “social risks”).1Smeed RJ Road pricing : the economic and technical possibilities.https://archive.org/details/op1265810-1001Date: 1964Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar Scarcity of data precluded quantification of whether road user charging would ameliorate these “social risks”,1Smeed RJ Road pricing : the economic and technical possibilities.https://archive.org/details/op1265810-1001Date: 1964Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar which are today known to be major threats to health and the environment. Smeed nonetheless recommended charges for driving on congested roads to reflect the wider costs of motor vehicle use. Successive British governments have failed to implement these recommendations, although momentum is now building for greater use of road user charging in local areas in the UK and internationally. In this Comment, we argue that although there remain challenges to overcome regarding policy design and public acceptability, the time has come for a more widespread implementation of road user charges to achieve health and environmental goals. Road user charges can be considered as an attempt to make the costs that motorists pay more closely reflect the costs to others from externalities, such as air pollution. A range of terms are used interchangeably, including road user charging, value pricing, or congestion charging, but such schemes charge motorists to use roads within a certain area or during a specified time frame. Charges can be levied upon entering a specified area at toll points (such as motorway tolls), for crossing into an area (known as cordon charging), or for any use within a specified area (known as area charging). A range of options exist for implementation, which can include varying the amounts charged and exemptions or reduced fees for particular vehicles or groups of people. Charges can vary by time of day, vehicle class, or a combination of vehicle type and assessment of emission standards. There is also flexibility around how to use any revenue raised; most commentators agree that revenue raised from road user charges should be used to improve alternative transport options.2Winslott-Hiselius L Brundell-Freij K Vagland Å Byström C The development of public attitudes towards the Stockholm congestion trial.Transp Res Part A Policy Pract. 2009; 43: 269-282Crossref Scopus (78) Google Scholar Use of motor transport has increased substantially in the UK and globally since the Smeed report, as has the evidence linking motor vehicles to health and environmental harms. For example, in 1962, cars, vans, and taxis accounted for 57% of the passenger distance travelled in the UK, which had risen to 83% by 2016.3Department for Transport StatisticsTable TSGB01. Passenger transport, by mode: annual from 1952.https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/482670/tsgb0101.xlsDate: 2017Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar Many of the recent road user charging schemes implemented in Europe have been driven by concerns about air pollution, which is an increasing focus of public concern. This is reflected in greater policy focus on creating low emission zones that focus not only on reducing the volume of private motor vehicle use, but also on substantially restricting the access of highly polluting vehicles.4Transport and the EnvironmentLow-emission zones are a success—but they must now move to zero-emission mobility.https://www.transportenvironment.org/sites/te/files/publications/2019_09_Briefing_LEZ-ZEZ_final.pdfDate: Sept, 2019Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar The direct evidence base for assessing these schemes is constrained by a low number of schemes in operation until very recently and a dearth of good-quality data. Natural experiments of previously implemented schemes have found stronger evidence for reducing traffic volumes than for health-related outcomes, although increases in physical activity due to switching to more active modes of transport, such as walking and cycling, have been identified.5Brown V Moodie M Carter R Congestion pricing and active transport—evidence from five opportunities for natural experiment.J Transp Health. 2015; 2: 568-579Crossref Scopus (11) Google Scholar Although the paucity of evaluations means that the evidence base is still emerging, we know that price is generally a much more important driver of consumer behaviour than education and information initiatives are. However, although price interventions are powerful, they tend to be politically contentious. In the UK, London led the way in 2003 with the first major road user charging system, the congestion charge, and in April, 2019, an extra levy was added to vehicles not meeting strict emission standards (known as the ultra-low emission zone). However, the congestion charge scheme suffered a setback in 2010, when the newly elected London mayor effectively halved the area covered by the scheme. The London example highlights the importance of building and maintaining public acceptability of road user charging before, during, and after implementation. This scheme followed a previously unsuccessful attempt by the centre-left Blair government to introduce a national road user charging scheme, which was dropped in 2007, after substantial negative media coverage and public outcry. However, growing popular concern about the health impacts of air pollution and the climate emergency could signal that road user charging is becoming more palatable to the public.6BBC NewsClimate strike: schoolchildren protest over climate change.https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-47250424Date: Feb 16, 2019Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar, 7Clayton N Jeffrey S Breach A Funding and financing inclusive growth in cities.http://www.centreforcities.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/17-12-11-Funding-and-Financing-for-Inclusive-Growth.pdfDate: Dec, 2017Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar Smeed was aware that one of the key criteria for any scheme to be effective was that effects “upon individual road users should be accepted as fair”.1Smeed RJ Road pricing : the economic and technical possibilities.https://archive.org/details/op1265810-1001Date: 1964Date accessed: October 13, 2020Google Scholar One important issue is that road user charging should not necessarily be uniform across geographical areas, to address the different needs, costs, and benefits of motorised transport between rural and urban settings.8Creutzig F Javaid A Koch N Knopf B Mattioli G Edenhofer O Adjust urban and rural road pricing for fair mobility.Nat Clim Chang. 2020; 10: 591-594Crossref Scopus (9) Google Scholar Residents in urban areas generally have access to alternative transport options, and trips typically involve shorter distances, which are more amenable to using non-motorised transport modes. The use of any revenue raised by road user charges is another opportunity to enhance its acceptability if it is done well. The acceptability of such schemes differs across sociodemographic groups, and many could feel negative about schemes, which they perceive as overly punitive.9Nikitas A Avineri E Parkhurst G Understanding the public acceptability of road pricing and the roles of older age, social norms, pro-social values and trust for urban policy-making: the case of Bristol.Cities. 2018; 79: 78-91Crossref Scopus (32) Google Scholar Road user charges are most likely to work well if there are clear but strong signals to motorists to avoid driving, which are connected to visible benefits for large sections of society. The Smeed report was correct in 1964 to state that the costs of road use should more closely reflect the costs borne by others. Since then, the factors that shape the way in which vehicles and people travel have changed substantially, including the direct and indirect costs of motor vehicles. Road user charging represents a promising but under-used mechanism to reduce motor vehicle use, thereby reducing harms and allowing investment in alternative options. There is the potential, as ever, for unintended harms, and as such schemes are planned and implemented, there is an important role for the research community to work in partnership with policy makers to assess their health and equity effects. Nonetheless, the climate emergency means that the time for widespread implementation of road user charging has now arrived. JP reports grants from the Medical Research Council during the conduct of this study. This study is linked to a research project funded by the UK National Institute for Health Research, School for Public Health Research (grant PD-SPH-2015).

title: Amplifying the voice of youth through planetary health films
display_name: Amplifying the voice of youth through planetary health films

author.au_affiliation_raw: Dahdaleh Institute for Global Health Research, York University, Toronto M3J 2S5, ON, Canada

ab: Young people should be engaged at international planetary health policy events and have their voices heard in a way that provides visible evidence of related issues in one easily accessible digital space. Researchers at the Dahdaleh Institute for Global Health Research (York University, Canada) have developed a programme that could help achieve this goal. The Planetary Health Film Lab is an intensive 1-week workshop that teaches participants from around the world how to create documentary films on planetary health issues relevant to their countries and communities. 1Dahdaleh Institute for Global Health ResearchPlanetary Health Film Lab.https://dighr.yorku.ca/projects/planetary-health-film-lab/Date: 2020Date accessed: November 16, 2020Google Scholar Films produced at The Planetary Health Film Lab contribute to a Geo-Doc, a remediated form of the documentary film created for the UN in 2015.2Terry M The geo-doc: geomedia, documentary film, and social change. Palgrave Macmillan, London2020Crossref Google Scholar The video curation project is part of the Youth Climate Report and is associated with the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). More than 450 videos produced by young people (aged 18–30 years) reside on the Geographic Information System global map, showcasing visible evidence of the research, effects, and solutions to climate change. Environmental advocacy projects, such as The Planetary Health Film Lab, provide young participants with the technical and theoretical tools to create these films and contribute directly to the Youth Climate Report. The first iteration of the Youth Climate Report was in response to a call by the UNFCCC in 2010 to provide video reports created by young people and the result was a feature-length documentary film containing five reports by individuals aged 18–30 years. The experiment was successfully received by the delegates of the Conference of Parties (COP) and resulted in increased demand for similar content. Clearly, the feature length format of a traditional documentary film could not accommodate this request. Therefore, a remediation of the documentary that incorporated structures known as database and multilinear filmmaking was proposed. This digital architecture allowed unlimited contribution of film uploads but there needed to be a platform that considered the specific user of this project, the UN. As new advancements in geomedia expanded the multimedia components of GIS content, video became a valuable new element.2Terry M The geo-doc: geomedia, documentary film, and social change. Palgrave Macmillan, London2020Crossref Google Scholar Video provided a platform that suited the international policy maker. Unlike other database documentary projects that require exploration throughout the host website, the Geo-Doc format allows an overarching global view through different film units. UN delegates could now easily select those film projects that related directly to the regions of the world that interested them most. Never intending to replace the scientific papers and written texts previously submitted to the policy maker, the Geo-Doc enhances these data by providing a visual context to the written word.2Terry M The geo-doc: geomedia, documentary film, and social change. Palgrave Macmillan, London2020Crossref Google Scholar In many cases, insufficient formal training in science meant that elected officials serving as policy advisers did not always understand the complex reports and peer-reviewed papers they were referencing. The Geo-Doc prototype was launched in Paris, France, at COP21 in 2015 and delegates responded favourably to the new format and the relative abundance of content. As a living documentary project (ie, new content can be added indefinitely) additional opportunities were conceived so that young people could contribute throughout the year. This concept gave rise to The Planetary Health Film Lab, an experimental curation project that brought young (aged 18–30 years) filmmakers from five continents together in an academic setting to create films about planetary health issues in their home countries and communities for the Youth Climate Report. The collaborative nature of the workshop allowed for the sharing of conceptual approaches to non-fiction filmmaking and exposure to multicultural perspectives on issues related to planetary health. This film lab workshop is designed to serve as a model for other planetary health research organisations, institutes, universities, and groups to host similar film labs and provide a continual supply of new video content to the UN Geo-Doc project. The inaugural film lab took place at York University in February, 2020. The seven participants were from Ecuador, Australia, Colombia, Canada, Italy, and India.3Tilleczek K MacDonald D The Planetary Health Film Lab evaluation report.http://youthclimatereport.org/uncategorized/planetary-health-film-lab-evaluation-reportDate: July 2, 2020Date accessed: November 16, 2020Google Scholar For the first 3 days, participants were taught by scholars and professionals experienced in communication, international policy, film production, digital media, and environmental studies. These lectures guided the participants both technically and theoretically in creating their own video report on planetary health issues in their respective home countries and communities. Days 4 and 5 were spent applying the knowledge they had been given in the production of their film reports. Professional support was provided by camera operators, film editors, documentary filmmakers, and sound recordists to assist the new filmmakers during this period of the film lab. By the end of the week, seven young people from six different countries premiered and introduced their films to the public at a small film festival held on campus. Their films were subsequently uploaded to the UN Youth Climate Report project, thus adding their voices to the global community of youth in anticipation of the 2021 COP26 climate summit (Glasgow, UK). The films supplied the Youth Climate Report with valuable content and the participants were encouraged to showcase their films when they returned to their home countries and share what they learned at the film lab with other young filmmakers to expand the reach of the project and produce more content that amplifies the voice of young people worldwide. The Planetary Health Film Lab has proven to be a successful approach to mobilising youth in the pursuit of creating informative and influential videos on the research, effects, and solutions related to planetary health issues. Using the remediated documentary film format of the Geo-Doc further extends this visible evidence to international policy makers, local governments, and the general public in a structure that is informative, influential, accessible, and comprehensive. MT reports grants from the Social Science and Humanities Research Council, outside of the submitted work.

title: A “super-year” for the environment
display_name: A “super-year” for the environment
ab: As we enter a new year and decade, it is natural to reflect on past progress and goals for the future. It's not surprising then that 2020 is shaping up to be a critical year in establishing ambition for climate and biodiversity action. There is much optimism and anticipation that this year could be a turning point in our relationship with nature, leading to the notion of 2020 being a "super year" for the environment. But this will only happen through conscious effort, if we drift on as we are, it will be far from super for people or the planet.

title: Ecological grief and hope in Vesper Flights
display_name: Ecological grief and hope in Vesper Flights
ab: Grief is necessary. Reading that “we are already inside the apocalypse” might sound bleak, but Helen Macdonald sees her new book as an effort to give much needed meaning to the loss of nature all around us. Creeping climate change, habitat loss, and mass extinction can be too much to comprehend beyond the bare numbers of science. As Macdonald writes in Vesper Flights, a collection of essays on various aspects of the natural world, we need literature “to communicate the value of things, so that more of us might fight to save them”. Macdonald gained acclaim for H is for Hawk, her deeply personal memoir about dealing with the loss of her father, which won her the Samuel Johnson Prize for non-fiction. Her new book weaves the political in with the personal, calling us to reconsider how we relate to the non-human world. Together with her naturalist's eye, Macdonald's training as a historian of science is part of what gives such depth to her writing; things are and are not what they seem. Her sensitivity to the changing meanings associated with particular animals and landscapes lends a precious quality and arresting power to the essays. In Vesper Flights, each essay transports you to a different place, and while many of them focus on her native UK, others jump to different parts of the world. One moment we are gazing up at masses of migrating birds high above New York's Empire State Building, thinking about the history of using radar to detect them; and another, we are watching boxing hares in a field near Macdonald's Suffolk home, reflecting on their symbolism as harbingers of spring and how that season has shrunk of late. A theme that weaves through the essays is how we tend to see ourselves in animals. National and natural histories often blur, and Macdonald explores how English swans have long been entwined with nationhood and identity, how postwar cuckoos were read as clandestine birds of deception and quiet murder, and how territorial anxieties spilled over into labelling some animals as unwanted invaders while absorbing other visitors as celebrated natives. What we see also depends on our emotional state, and in other essays Macdonald examines how a creature or natural phenomenon revealed something about herself. As she told me over Zoom, “we need science to understand the complexities of ecosystems and climate systems, but we also need to think about our emblematic uses of animals and landscapes, how and why we value them culturally and at an individual level, and these two kinds of understanding need to happen together”. We can't help but see the natural world through the associations and metaphors we've built during our lives; encounters with animals are “always already emblematic”. Rather than attempting to deny what is there, Macdonald illuminates these often hidden meanings, that we might then work with them. Then again, our metaphors never quite fit. Another recurring refrain is Macdonald stepping back from symbolism to emphasise that nature is not there for us. In one essay, falcons nesting on high-rises seem to shift their identity as romantic icons of threatened wilderness into a reflection of our own fascination with vision and surveillance. And yet, she writes, “their greatest magic is that they're not human at all”. Part of the essays’ brilliance is their dance between exploring and cherishing the emblematic meanings we project onto the natural world, and insisting that the non-human world is more. This is the sticking point of the instrumentalist idea that natural places are good for our mental and physical health. It's not that we shouldn't think about the value of the natural world for us, Helen told me, but we also need to extend empathy towards creatures that aren't like us, and value other species for themselves. A beautiful landscape to us might be like a desert for many species. Perhaps the most overarching theme of the studies, though, is the sense of needing to take stock of the natural world while we still can. The essays repeatedly chart losses of non-human life, like the disappearance of a meadow she adored as a child. “None of us can bear too much reality”, Macdonald writes, but she points out that in an earlier sense of the word apocalypse, it meant a revelation. As we talked, she explained that “bearing witness” is a big aim of the book, adding that “we need to feel grief first in order move forward and grant ourselves agency to bring about change”. One essay reflects on our incomprehension of systemic climate change, and in our conversation, Helen was clear that we need more than the dominant narrative of individuals making small choices to help the environment; we need to cause “good trouble” to help bring about “massive structural changes”. “Apocalyptic thinking is a powerful antagonist to action”, she writes, but many of the essays signal a stinging sense of hope, and as we talked, she stressed “the importance of hope that ruin is not inevitable”. The essays are a tribute to the complexity of non-human life and our relationship with it, and a call to notice change despite the discomfort that brings, with the hope that this might inspire positive action.

title: In sight but out of mind
display_name: In sight but out of mind
ab: We opened this year with the hope that 2020 could be a super year for the environment with major policy milestones on biological conservation and climate policy. Regrettably, much of that agenda has been blown out of the water by COVID-19. However, while media bandwidth has been almost entirely consumed by the pandemic, and its political and economic fallout, 2020 has been unprecedented in other ways as well.

title: Decarbonising economies is like denuclearising weaponry—essential for survival
display_name: Decarbonising economies is like denuclearising weaponry—essential for survival

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Geography and the Environment, Oxford University, Oxford OX1 3QY, UK

ab: Humanity has been here before, facing what appeared to be an imminent end (figure).1Dorling D The equality effect: improving life for everyone. New Internationalist, Oxford2017Google Scholar The rise in nuclear weapons was rapid, from the first two used on Aug 6 and Aug 9, 1945, through to 10 000 held by 1960, almost 40 000 in 1970, and peaking at over 60 000 in the mid-1980s. At the time, it did not feel like a peak; it felt as if we were all going to die.2Bulletin of the Atomic ScientistsNuclear notebook: nuclear arsenals of the world.https://thebulletin.org/nuclear-notebook-multimedia/Date: 2020Date accessed: March 25, 2020Google Scholar In the 1930s, a few people knew that nuclear weapons would be potentially cataclysmic. By the 1960s, there was a well-established anti-nuclear weapon peace movement, but the protestors were treated as fools by the media. By the 1980s, it was becoming clear that nuclear war was mass annihilation and could not be avoided by threats of mutually assured destruction. Disarmament began in earnest. The climate emergency has a similar trajectory,3Ellis E Science alone won't save the Earth. People have to do that: we need to start talking about what kind of planet we want to live on.https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/11/opinion/sunday/science-people-environment-earth.htmlDate: Aug 11, 2018Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar but without that most imminent of threats. People's reaction to both is similar: ignorance, acceptance, revulsion, and rejection, but only generation by generation. People tend to stick with what they believed as teenagers. Today's teenagers know that the climate emergency is real, just as the teenagers who put flowers in the barrels of guns in the 1960s knew what their parents did not. In the 1970s, hardly anyone knew that greenhouse gases would be potentially cataclysmic.3Ellis E Science alone won't save the Earth. People have to do that: we need to start talking about what kind of planet we want to live on.https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/11/opinion/sunday/science-people-environment-earth.htmlDate: Aug 11, 2018Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar By the 2000s, there was a well-established climate emergency movement, but the protestors were treated as fools by many.4Chatterton P The climate emergency and the new civic role for the university: as we face a climate emergency, universities must undergo radical change to lead the way in tackling the crisis.https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/climate-emergency-and-new-civic-role-universityDate: June 21, 2019Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar By 2019, it become clear that if left unabated, global heating would be disastrous and could not be avoided by the market foreseeing our assured destruction.5Goodall A Oswald A Researchers obsessed with FT journals list are failing to tackle today's problems.https://www.ft.com/content/b820d6f2-7016-11e9-bf5c-6eeb837566c5Date: May 8, 2019Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar Decarbonisation began in earnest, while millions marched to proclaim that this was not enough. Then, in 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic provided many people who have not experienced such turmoil before with an insight into what happens when normal life is up-ended. No-one who is sane would choose or welcome in any way the shock of the 2020 pandemic emergency, but it has caused a much more rapid economic and consumption slowdown than would otherwise have ever been possible. The virus initially reduced CO2 emissions from China by a quarter, before they began to plummet worldwide,6Myllyvirta L Analysis: coronavirus has temporarily reduced China's CO2 emissions by a quarter.https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-coronavirus-has-temporarily-reduced-chinas-co2-emissions-by-a-quarterDate: Feb 19, 2020Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar and the small number of human beings alive who can afford to fly internationally have been forced to dramatically reduce their international air flights.7Pham S The coronavirus has grounded Chinese tourists. The global travel industry may not recover for years.https://edition.cnn.com/2020/02/28/business/global-tourism-novel-coronavirus/index.htmlDate: Feb 28, 2020Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar The pandemic has also illustrated how rapid and unified global action to protect health is possible when there is a political will. A global demographic and economic slowdown had begun long before the virus hit. In a post-pandemic world, it would be unforgivable to simply return to business as usual. An acceleration of the slowdown that was already occurring before the pandemic began is humanity's hope and should be our aim.8Dorling D Slowdown: the end of the great acceleration—and why it's good for the planet, the economy, and our lives. Yale University Press, New Haven and London2020Crossref Google Scholar Shifting to a longer timescale, since life began on Earth, there have been five major mass extinction events.9Wells WD The uninhabitable earth: a story of the future. Allen Lane, London2019Google Scholar Six out of seven of all the planet's species died 450 million years ago due to global cooling. Three-quarters were wiped out 370 million years ago, again due to climate change, and 250 million years ago, after another rapid climate change of 5°C warming, 24 of every 25 species became extinct. Some 200 million years ago, the climate changed again, and four of every five species on Earth were wiped out. The last of the great five mass extinctions occurred around 65 million years ago, when an asteroid that was 6–9 miles wide hit Earth, and three out of four of all species became extinct. Today, we are just a few decades into the sixth and most rapid of all mass extinctions. Humanity has had a worse and faster effect on the biodiversity of the planet than a huge asteroid. The good news is that if you take extinction as the disappearance in sexual species of the very last breeding pair, then extinction is quite hard to achieve, although by no means impossible. The bad news is that this is not really the kind of extinction that matters for the wider environment. What matters most is the extinction of function: a species no longer having the numbers to fully play its part in the web of connections.10Säterberg T Sellman S Ebenman B High frequency of functional extinctions in ecological networks.Nature. 2013; 499: 468-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar The planet can be saved—if we care enough to do so. Today, as Matthew Taylor and Jessica Murray observed, "…there is no way to completely shield young people from the reality of the climate crisis, and that would be counterproductive even if it were possible. Rather, parents should talk to their children about their concerns and help them feel empowered to take action",11Taylor M Murray J 'Overwhelming and terrifying': the rise of climate anxiety.https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/feb/10/overwhelming-and-terrifying-impact-of-climate-crisis-on-mental-healthDate: Feb 10, 2020Date accessed: April 2, 2020Google Scholar just as a few of their parents and grandparents did before them to avert nuclear catastrophe. The emerging lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic give us an opportunity profoundly to re-evaluate our humanity, including a far more careful consideration of those yet to be born. Our future remains in our hands. I declare no competing interests. Adaptive anxiety

title: Walking forwards, looking backwards
display_name: Walking forwards, looking backwards
ab: Scanning back over news headlines from this year throws up a lot of references to events being unprecedented and unexpected and to many societal responses as being relatively underprepared, unplanned, or poorly tested, especially where multiple stressors overlap. Indeed, if we lacked useful and meaningful foresight and could only learn from past experience, then that would be our inevitable predicament. 2020 has been remarkable in many respects to the extent that even listing the examples would take up most of the available space for this editorial.

title: Planetary Health Research Digest
display_name: Planetary Health Research Digest
ab: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) aims to stabilise the worldwide monetary system, and by doing so promote economic growth and reduce global poverty. To do so, the IMF provides loans to countries experiencing economic difficulties. However, the conditions attached to these loans—particularly those related to economic liberalisation through structural adjustment—have been criticised for their lack of focus on health equity. To test whether participation in IMF loan programmes affected health equity, Timon Forster (Freie Universität Berlin, Germany, Germany) and co-authors analysed IMF-mandated policy reforms in 137 developing countries from 1980 to 2014. While participation in an IMF loan programme did not in itself significantly affect health-care access or neonatal mortality (the chosen metrics of health equity), both indicators were adversely affected by the number of policy reforms included as conditions for these loans. In particular, reforms affecting labour markets were found to be driving these effects. If the IMF is to achieve its stated goals of reducing poverty, the authors conclude, it will need to make health equity central to future programmes, not just efficiency. Nature-based solutions are an increasingly common concept in discussions around climate change adaptation and mitigation, especially in urban environments. While most research on nature-based solutions has focused on defining them or refining their implementation, less attention has been paid to the political assumptions underlying their use and popularity. In their analysis, Panagiota Kotsila (Institute of Environmental Science and Technology, Spain) and co-authors discuss the role of nature-based solutions in the neoliberalisation of nature, using two case studies from Barcelona to illustrate the differences in how such projects can play out. The first case, the establishment of a green corridor on the Passeig de Sant Joan, is used as an illustration of a project in which urban nature ends up being used for mainly economic benefit, with the chosen design of the greenspace being one that largely favoured café and bar owners in the area, rather than wildlife or communal social space. The second case, community gardens in Espai Germanetes, started from a similar economic motivation, with nature being used to prevent property degradation during a period of economic hardship. Despite this, the project transcended these goals when local community members successfully fought for the permanent establishment of their gardens, negating the original use of nature to protect future property investment. As the authors show, nature-based solutions are not necessarily apolitical and their implementation deserves study to answer whether they are delivering on their promise of true sustainability. Permafrost soils contain more than half of the total soil carbon in the world. Warming in permafrost zones and subsequent decomposition of this soil carbon has the potential to release a substantial amount of carbon into the atmosphere. Existing models have estimated the potential carbon release from the slow thawing of these permafrost zones, but sizable areas of these zones are also at risk for abrupt thawing. Merritt Turetsky (Institute of Arctic and Alpine Research, University of Colorado, USA) and co-authors synthesise the existing evidence and develop models to estimate abrupt thawing in their analyses of permafrost carbon release. Under Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) 8·5 warming, the climate impacts of emissions from the 2·5 million km2 at risk of abrupt thawing were similar in magnitude to those from the wider 18 million km2 permafrost zone, at around 600 Tg CO2 equivalent per year from 2000–2100. Under RCP 4·5 warming, vegetation growth in thawed areas has been estimated to result in net ecosystem carbon uptake; however, when the authors factored abrupt thawing into their model, the additional emissions outweighed the carbon sink effects. Turetsky and colleagues argue that by not accounting for abrupt thawing, previous models have substantially underestimated the potential carbon emissions from thawing permafrost. Responses at the policy level are crucial for addressing major challenges such as the global obesity epidemic or climate change, and public support is essential to making sure that these policies are implemented effectively. Although communicating the effectiveness of a given policy is a logical way to increase public support for it, there is concern that this might not be the case in a “post-truth” world of echo chambers and political polarisation. On the basis of this uncertainty, James Reynolds (University of Cambridge, UK) and co-authors conducted a systematic review with meta-analysis of studies in which evidence of effectiveness or ineffectiveness was presented to members of the public for specific policies to investigate whether support for these policies then changed. Overall, support for a policy increased where participants were provided with evidence of effectiveness, and decreased with evidence of ineffectiveness or harm, with changes equivalent to an increase from 50% to 54% or a decrease from 50% to 44%, respectively. The findings suggest that aggregate policy support can move in the direction of the evidence provided for the public, highlighting the importance for effective communication in evidence-based policy making.

title: Picking winners
display_name: Picking winners
ab: Natural selection tends to inspire in people imagery of nature “red in tooth and claw” with intense competition favouring genes carried by the individuals that compete the hardest and fastest. There is some truth in these images, but they are incomplete; natural selection works in many varied and subtle ways depending on the particular context, for example favouring nurturing behaviour in certain situations and an individual's strength can be demonstrated by shows of generosity (pro-social behaviour) as well as domination. Furthermore, deliberate selective breeding can favour all kinds of traits, as we see in domestic dogs for example. This is not just of intellectual interest to biologists, ideas about natural selection and notions of highly individualistic behaviours have influenced microeconomic ideas implying for many that markets follow natural principals that largely constrain what can work in practice. For proponents of this view it follows that climate, biodiversity, and social equity must be addressed within quite specific constraints and any other view is generally suggested to be naive and idealistic. In striving to solve societies problems, it can be argued that we are endeavouring to understand the balance between what is desirable and what is possible. In this attempt some people tend to err on the side of the desirable— imagining how the world could be better— and others tend to err on the side of the possible—focussing on the more immediately practical and feasible. Clearly this is a simplification, but nevertheless the prevalence of these viewpoints and the emphasis put upon them in the halls of power and influence and related structures provides an important part of the selective environment in which new ideas, practices and technologies must survive and prosper. COVID-19 has precipitated an acute crisis. Climate heating, biodiversity collapse, and social injustice are all chronic intersecting conditions that have deep roots. In combination they require fundamental and transformative changes within society, however, finding consensus on the solutions is challenging and there is an abundance of different ideas about how to mitigate climate change, reverse biodiversity loss, and reduce social inequality. The point here is that while there are of course constraints on what is possible, there is not just one type of selective outcome. The attributes that prosper are a product of their selective environment and, much like dog breeding, we can select traits that we wish to see more of. Currently we tend to throw new ideas, technologies and practices into essentially the same old socioeconomic and political environment. The very environment which selected for the traits which are responsible for environmental degradation and social inequality. No matter how many good ideas and technologies are thrown into that pool, selection will continue to favour many of the same old traits. For example, many environmentally sustainable businesses are relatively small scale, often by design, with relatively small turnover. Such businesses tend not to be able to invest in costly advertising. So, you won't see many large-scale advertising campaigns for green but relatively low profit products and brands, even if they have substantial environmental benefits over existing ones; think menstrual cups versus disposable pads. This might sound like a modest issue. However, advertising is a pervasive form of messaging in our lives and for many people, their notions of success are tied to purchasing power for certain types of brands, products, and services. Because of the need for high sales volume, many of the most profitable product lines intrinsically involve a great deal of energy and material to produce. This context makes it very hard for sustainable ideas and products to get mainstream marketing except through the modified (often greenwashed) campaigns of multinationals. It is not that multinationals are intrinsically bad, but that there are currently many incentives that push them towards poor environmental records. This kind of selection makes it hard for multinationals to make really significant improvements in environmental standards and for newcomers to outcompete the establishment. This is just one example of a kind of selective inertia that makes change difficult. Unless the incentive structures constituting the selective environment for what society chooses can be adapted to select greener traits, it seems that a great deal of effort and creativity will be simply outcompeted by more damaging norms. This is perhaps the essence of what systematic change requires. Moon-shot initiatives for the environment are welcome and have a place but without the right environment in which to prosper, their impact will likely be small and short lived.

title: Turning point?
display_name: Turning point?
ab: Climate change is a collective action problem, but because some countries like the United States are particularly high emitters—as well as having wider economic and political influence—they play an outsized role in setting the political landscape for international climate action. Consequently, it is likely that the Paris Climate Agreement struck in 2015 would have been less successful if the US was not on board. That situation of course changed after the 2016 US presidential elections as the Trump administration took office with a clear stance against climate policy, climate science, and environmental regulation in general. A great deal of environmental legislation was rolled back, and support for coal, oil, and gas sectors ramped up. That attitude towards climate policy, as well as an aversion to international governance, was a huge blow to the chances of meeting the Paris Agreement objective of limiting climate heating to 2°C above pre-industrial temperatures (and ideally just 1·5°C). The Trump administration's intentions came to fruition in early November this year when the US became the first nation to formally withdraw from the Paris Agreement. In spite of this context many regional administrations have continued to push forward decarbonization under the banner We Are Still In, but domestic policies have hamper efforts at the national level. The transfer of leadership in 2021 to Joe Biden and Kamala Harris after the recent election promises to flip the US government's attitude towards climate policy in a dramatic way. The Biden-Harris administration may not be as climate progressive as some hoped, but they have by far the most ambitious US government climate strategy to date. On the campaign trail, Biden outlined plans to re-join the Paris Agreement, early in his term, and commit to net zero carbon emissions by 2050. He pledged to spend $2 trillion over 4 years improving building efficiency (with a special provision for disadvantaged communities), decarbonising public transport, investing in electric vehicle manufacturing and charging infrastructure, and incentivising consumers to buy cleaner cars in a twin effort to decarbonise and create jobs. Of course delivering on those promises will be trickier. The election revealed an American populace deeply divided; combined with a less than decisive Democrat performance in the Senate race, the Biden-Harris administration will have an uphill task enacting their climate policies. Domestic US policy success will be materially important and will also serve as an indicator of climate credibility. However, the outward facing attitude of the government could also be important. Biden's aim to “lead an effort to get every major country to ramp up [decarbonisation] ambition”, and to shame “climate outlaws” who are not delivering, or are stalling progress, is itself a potentially significant step in the right direction. America is not the only big emitter, of course, and China made an important step in committing to Net zero emissions by 2060 back in October. President Xi's announcement, which surprised many outside of China, represents another important step towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions globally. Combined with the European Union's 2050 net zero commitment, these developments in China and the US are starting to provide a sense of momentum in the lead up to the 26th session of the Conference of Parties (COP26) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), in Glasgow in November next year. Continuing reductions in the price of renewables, allowed the International Energy Agency's World Energy Outlook 2020 to announce that the best performing solar power schemes now offer the “cheapest…electricity in history”. Encouraging political alignment on net zero commitments also sends a loud and clear message to the private sector, and combined with increasingly competitive renewable energy means that perhaps for the first time there is a real sense that serious decarbonisation in line with the Paris Agreement is possible. Possible is far from inevitable though. Health professionals, researchers, campaigners, and activists, as well as entrepreneurs, engineers, governors, teachers, and everybody concerned with, or about, climate change still have much to do. So far national governments have mostly responded to pressure rather than taking a lead. This implies they need to be pushed further in their ambition and held accountable to their existing pledges. Any instances of backsliding and creative accounting must be quickly exposed and overturned. There is every chance that momentum will build around a clean and healthy recovery from COVID-19 which could even surpass our expectations, but not if we stop pushing.

title: Weighing the risks
display_name: Weighing the risks
ab: Every year, the World Economic Forum (WEF) releases a Global Risk Report in an effort to integrate the major risks posed to society over the coming decade. The report is based upon a poll of WEF members and a wider stakeholder group—for the 2020 report, the survey included around 1000 representatives from business, government, academia, and civil society. This exercise provides a common framework in which to compare diverse risks, from asset bubbles to weapons of mass destruction and extreme weather events. Risks are categorised in terms of their impact and likelihood and presented on a matrix with those that are most concerning (with high impact and high likelihood) at the top right of the matrix. In the 2020 report, environmental risks dominate this “corner of most concern”, making up the top five risks by likelihood (“extreme weather events”, “climate action failure”, “natural disasters”, “biodiversity loss” and “human-made environmental disasters”) and the first, third and fourth top risks by impact. The WHO undertook a comparable exercise to list 13 “Urgent global health challenges for the 2020s”. Although this list is not ranked, threats directly or indirectly related to the state of the environment feature strongly, notably including the need to elevate health in the climate debate. Nine out of ten people are exposed to polluted air every day leading to an estimated 7 million premature deaths per year. Climate change is expected to cause increasingly negative health outcomes through a host of effects such as increases in malnutrition, the spread of vector-borne disease, and heat stress. Air pollution and climate change are intimately linked through the burning of fossil fuels which are primarily responsible for both phenomena. Climate policies require steep declines in fossil fuel use and this could go a long way towards improving air quality. So far, so unsurprising. These two recent efforts further highlight that the environment is now a major risk to lives and livelihoods, rather than being some abstract object of moral concern. From an academic perspective, we have arrived at this insight via enormous strides in understanding of the complexities of natural systems and the ways in which they are impacted by, and can impact upon, people. In short, we have already identified many of the health and sustainability challenges of our time and how they interconnect. We know the major causes and we know in broad terms what we need to do to improve things. Regrettably, both of these reports also contain insights into why progressing from knowledge to action is so often difficult in practice. A notable entry in the WHO list is “Earning public trust”. Public health is being compromised by the dissemination of misinformation through social media, and the erosion of trust in public institutions, the anti-vaccination movement has also contributed to a rise in deaths from preventable diseases. The reasons for vaccine hesitancy are complex, and factors identified include inconvenience of access, lack of confidence and complacency (many of these diseases are now relatively rare precisely because of vaccination). The lack of confidence is particularly concerning given that vaccination is a long proven and extremely cost-effective health intervention. The rise of vaccine hesitancy seems to be reflective of wider difficulties in taking robust academic knowledge through to public acceptance and practical application. The basic problem of moving from knowledge to action is not new; time and again vested interest has been able to combat overwhelming evidence to push a competing agenda. However, the power of evidence to persuade does seem to be at a low point. Perhaps social media should take some of the blame, because of its emphasis on soundbite and the tendency for echo chambers of opinion to emerge. But whatever the cause, we appear to be firmly ensconced in an era of post-truth debate and increasing personal and political populism. This polarisation, combined with the fundamental challenge that living within planetary boundaries poses to the sociopolitical and economic status quo make the process of turning knowledge into real change more challenging even than generating that knowledge in the first place. Much as we need to continue to refine our understanding of key sustainability challenges and map out viable solutions, it is insight into the theoretical and practical means to achieve acceptance and implement change that will most determine planetary health in the coming decades.

title: Decline and denial
display_name: Decline and denial
ab: Global wildlife populations are in freefall. This is the conclusion of a recent WWF report. That might sound like dramatic language but how else should you describe a global situation in which animal populations (mammals, birds, fish, amphibians, and reptiles) have fallen on average by 68% since 1970? To bring this down to the personal, that means all but the youngest among us were born into a world much richer in natural life than the one we now inhabit, and if we don't change course that will be everybody's legacy. This report is one of the latest in a raft of work showing just how severely human activities are impacting life on earth. A common economic refrain is to argue that economic development initially degrades the environment, but then after a time further development begins to reduce degradation—an idea described by the environmental Kuznets curve. Extending this notion, it would be tempting to think that if we wait long enough, wealth creation will resolve most environmental problems. Unfortunately that downturn in environmental damages simply is not happening at any meaningful scale and, as a new UN report shows, the world has failed to meet a single one of the Aichi biodiversity targets that were intended to encourage reductions in biodiversity loss between 2010 and 2020. Perhaps it is a symptom of increasingly urban lifestyles and a reduction in the proportion of people with a direct and tangible dependence on the natural world that more people are not personally outraged and worried by the decline of nature. Damages that have terrible consequences for marginalised people and for all future generations and as described in a Comment by Kathryn Fiorella and colleagues impacts can feed back to further exacerbate environmental degradation. In a book review of Helen Macdonald's Vesper Flights, Sophia Davis explores the book's thesis that we need to notice environmental degradation despite the discomfort it brings. Beyond a degree of personal insulation from nature, there is also a pervading narrative of progress; that things are changing for the better and that the benefits will gradually spread across the globe. In short, keep doing what we are doing, and all will be well. This narrative, as with the Kuznets curve, suits rich and powerful interests, which gain most from the status quo and have the most to lose from changing it. These examples are illustrative of a wider range of habits of living and thinking which tend to undervalue the importance of nature and separate the majority of people from experiencing ecological loss. Fortunately, scientific evidence of ecological crisis is beginning to sway public opinion towards an understanding of how bad things are and therefore an openness to how things might need to change. With depressing predictability though the scientific consensus is not going unchallenged and extinction denialism is the latest in a litany of science denial agendas circulating on the internet and social media platforms. Intended to muddy the waters on what is known about, to name but a few, climate change, pandemic risk, vaccine safety, and now biodiversity decline, these agendas aim to win hearts and minds in favour of the status quo. It can seem tempting to discount these claims as ridiculous and ill-founded but they have the potential to be deeply damaging to the political progress needed to make meaningful changes, in this case against ecological loss. In the age of Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube it is hard not to consume tailored information that is often filtered so that it tends to reinforce existing points of view. This echo chamber effect may be one of the drivers of political polarisation and probably enables science denialism because theories with overwhelming scientific consensus can be presented as outlandish and driven by vested interest with little challenge within a given echo chamber. Researchers and experts need to provide compelling explanations and counterarguments in these same forums. In her book Why Trust Science? Naomi Oreskes attempts to tackle science denialism as a political strategy. If political progress is not to be blocked by effective lobbying, it is all of our jobs to increase trust in science as a means to inform policy. Oreskes argues that we will not do this by simply giving people more information, but rather scientists will be more persuasive if they are able to communicate the values that motivate them and shape the science they produce. Feedbacks from human health to household reliance on natural resources during the COVID-19 pandemicOriginating from the wildlife trade and emerging as a global pandemic, COVID-19 has shown how exploitation of natural resources can negatively affect human health. More broadly, there is growing recognition of the diverse ways that environmental degradation (eg, deforestation and climate change) negatively affects human health through myriad pathways (eg, increased risk of disease spillover from wildlife to humans). Less attention has been given to how human health then feeds back to affect the environment and exacerbate harm to people. Full-Text PDF Open AccessEcological grief and hope in Vesper FlightsGrief is necessary. Reading that “we are already inside the apocalypse” might sound bleak, but Helen Macdonald sees her new book as an effort to give much needed meaning to the loss of nature all around us. Creeping climate change, habitat loss, and mass extinction can be too much to comprehend beyond the bare numbers of science. As Macdonald writes in Vesper Flights, a collection of essays on various aspects of the natural world, we need literature “to communicate the value of things, so that more of us might fight to save them”. Full-Text PDF Open Access

topics.display_name: Renewable Energy, Sustainability and the Environment

title: Planetary health research digest
display_name: Planetary health research digest
ab: Household energy supplies help to maintain comfortable temperatures, ventilate homes and preserve food in the face of environmental stressors. However, many households face energy insecurity, putting them at risk of a range of health threats. In order to better characterise who is most at risk of energy insecurity around the world and the mechanisms by which it affects wellbeing, Sonal Jessel (Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, USA) and co-authors conducted a review of the literature on the physical, economic, and health dimensions of this problem. They then develop a new model to help understand energy insecurity. A key conclusion is that the people most affected by energy insecurity are usually those who are already facing other hardships, such as those resulting from racial, socioeconomic, or gender inequality. Future research will need to account for energy insecurity as a mediator of social inequality, as well as the effects of climate change. Global food production relies heavily on breadbasket regions, which produce disproportionately large shares of global food supplies. Crop failure in these regions due to climate extremes is therefore a key concern for global food security. While failure in a single breadbasket can often be compensated by trade or crop reserves, simultaneous failures are harder to absorb. Franziska Gaupp (International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, Austria) and co-authors investigate how the changing climate has affected the risk of crop failures in global breadbasket regions between 1967 and 2012. Using data on crop yields and climate conditions to define adverse growing conditions for four staple crops, they found substantial increases in the risk of simultaneous breadbasket failures for wheat, maize, and soybeans, while the risk was decreased for rice. Modelling the spatial dependence of climate between regions indicated that climate conditions in one region could exacerbate or mitigate the risk of breadbasket failure posed to other regions, further illustrating the complexity of the processes involved. Such analyses could help to inform resiliency or contingency programmes to avoid future food system shocks. The global stock of residential buildings is rapidly growing. To reduce waste, materials from older buildings could be repurposed in the construction of newer ones. The scaling up of building material recycling requires systematic estimates of the current stocks of these materials. Sylvia Marinova (Leiden University, the Netherlands) and co-authors address this knowledge gap by compiling the first global database of building material intensities for residential buildings and test its usefulness for modelling future scenarios of housing and material stocks. They construct the database using the findings from previous smaller scale studies and test its applicability by modelling changes in stocks from 1970–2050 under a middle-of-the road scenario for future development. While housing and material stocks were predicted to continue growing slowly in high-income countries, China led in overall growth, particularly for in-use steel stocks, with evidence of this growth plateauing by around 2050. In other rapidly developing regions such as India and southeast Asia this growth in housing stocks has recently started to increase and is projected to continue rising past 2050. By making the database available, the authors offer a first step towards improved recycling of in-use building materials. Since the publication of the Summary for Policymakers of the IPBES Global Assessment in May, 2019, the threats to biodiversity have garnered increased attention. Sandra Diaz (Instituto Multidisciplinario de Biología Vegetal, Argentina) and co-authors summarise the key findings of the IPBES assessment and bring it up to date with evidence published since the end of the literature review phase. They outline the staggering scale of human impacts on biodiversity, not just in terms of the numbers of species threatened with extinction, but also the declines in nature's ability to contribute to human quality of life. By reviewing the direct and indirect drivers of environmental change and the impact of these changes on progress towards human and environmental wellbeing targets, such as the SDGs, the authors define key leverage points for effecting positive change towards a more sustainable future. They argue that use of these levers, such as incentivisation of sustainable behaviour and enhancing intersectoral collaboration, could still avoid and even reverse some of the harms done to Earths biodiversity; but transformational changes are required.

title: Correction to Lancet Planet Health 2020; 4: e7–8
